<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 185, 170, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 248, 590, 293]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 599, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 892, 403]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 534, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 448, 91]]<|/det|> A cyclist rides round a track three times. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 97, 791, 212]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 225, 920, 260]]<|/det|> Her friend uses a stopwatch to record the time at the start of the ride, after one circuit, and at the end of the three circuits. The readings from the stopwatch are shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 266, 839, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 549, 402]]<|/det|> What is the average time for one circuit of the track? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 412, 133, 430]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 413, 198, 430]]<|/det|> 174 s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 413, 301, 430]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 413, 366, 430]]<|/det|> 180 s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 413, 470, 430]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 413, 534, 430]]<|/det|> 198 s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 413, 636, 432]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 413, 700, 432]]<|/det|> 200 s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 457, 99, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 457, 744, 477]]<|/det|> The graph shows how the distance travelled by a vehicle changes with time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 483, 756, 655]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 735, 689]]<|/det|> Which row describes the speed of the vehicle in each section of the graph? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 700, 581, 829]]<|/det|>
P to QQ to RR to S
Aconstantzeroconstant
Bconstantzerodecreasing
Cincreasingconstantdecreasing
Dincreasingzerodecreasing

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 512, 89]]<|/det|> A small steel ball is dropped from a low balcony. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 626, 120]]<|/det|> Ignoring air resistance, which statement describes its motion? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 428, 147]]<|/det|> It falls with constant acceleration. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 134, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 156, 378, 174]]<|/det|> It falls with constant speed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 134, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 183, 398, 201]]<|/det|> It falls with decreasing speed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 134, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 209, 440, 227]]<|/det|> It falls with increasing acceleration. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 253, 96, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 598, 272]]<|/det|> Which is the unit for force and which is the unit for weight? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 371, 411]]<|/det|>
forceweight
Akgkg
BkgN
CNkg
DNN
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 439, 96, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 439, 326, 457]]<|/det|> A cup contains hot liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 469, 369, 486]]<|/det|> Some of the liquid evaporates. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 498, 682, 516]]<|/det|> What happens to the mass and to the weight of the liquid in the cup? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 528, 547, 655]]<|/det|>
massweight
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesstays the same

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 584, 89]]<|/det|>
A student is given four different objects and a metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 85, 841, 120]]<|/det|>
Each object has a known mass. She is asked to determine the densities of the material which the four objects are made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 784, 149]]<|/det|>
The objects are a copper cylinder, a glass cube, a steel spanner and a stone tile.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 154, 855, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 299, 870, 317]]<|/det|>
Using only the metre rule, she is able to find the densities of only three of the four materials.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 393, 348]]<|/det|>
Which three materials are these?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 358, 134, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 346, 377]]<|/det|>
copper, glass and steel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 134, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 384, 351, 403]]<|/det|>
copper, glass and stone

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 410, 133, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 410, 346, 428]]<|/det|>
copper, steel and stone

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 133, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 435, 336, 454]]<|/det|>
glass, steel and stone

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 479, 96, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 841, 497]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show a steel spring and a graph of its length against the load applied to it.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 508, 833, 828]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 845, 702, 864]]<|/det|>
What is the extension of the spring when a load of \(20\mathrm{N}\) is applied to it?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 874, 133, 892]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 874, 210, 892]]<|/det|>
3.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 874, 298, 892]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 874, 376, 892]]<|/det|>
4.5 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 874, 467, 892]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 874, 544, 892]]<|/det|>
5.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 874, 635, 892]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 874, 710, 892]]<|/det|>
8.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 757, 92]]<|/det|>
A box is being moved by a fork-lift truck. The total weight of the box is 3000 N.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 98, 695, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 280, 680, 301]]<|/det|>
The force exerted by the fork-lift truck on the box is 3500 N upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 437, 331]]<|/det|>
What is the resultant force on the box?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 341, 134, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 341, 301, 358]]<|/det|>
500 N downwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 367, 133, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 367, 278, 384]]<|/det|>
500 N upwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 134, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 393, 312, 411]]<|/det|>
6500 N downwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 133, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 420, 288, 439]]<|/det|>
6500 N upwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 463, 94, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 771, 482]]<|/det|>
An aeroplane is landing. As it descends towards the runway, its speed reduces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 492, 656, 512]]<|/det|>
What are the energy changes that take place during the descent?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 133, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 522, 495, 541]]<|/det|>
kinetic + gravitational \(\rightarrow\) thermal (heat)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 133, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 551, 495, 568]]<|/det|>
kinetic \(\rightarrow\) gravitational + thermal (heat)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 578, 133, 596]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 578, 495, 596]]<|/det|>
kinetic + thermal (heat) \(\rightarrow\) gravitational

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 133, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 606, 495, 624]]<|/det|>
thermal (heat) \(\rightarrow\) kinetic + gravitational

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 648, 106, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 648, 787, 667]]<|/det|>
Energy from uranium is transferred to electrical energy in a nuclear power station.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 677, 569, 696]]<|/det|>
What is the correct order of the stages of this process?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 131, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 480, 725]]<|/det|>
boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) reactor \(\rightarrow\) turbine

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 735, 131, 753]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 735, 480, 753]]<|/det|>
generator \(\rightarrow\) boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbine \(\rightarrow\) reactor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 763, 131, 781]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 763, 480, 781]]<|/det|>
reactor \(\rightarrow\) boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbine \(\rightarrow\) generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 790, 133, 809]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 790, 480, 808]]<|/det|>
reactor \(\rightarrow\) turbine \(\rightarrow\) boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 603, 91]]<|/det|>
It is dangerous for submarines to dive to very great depths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 292, 120]]<|/det|>
Why is it dangerous?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 529, 149]]<|/det|>
The density of water is less at greater depths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 158, 133, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 571, 176]]<|/det|>
The pressure of water is greater at greater depths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 589, 201]]<|/det|>
The temperature of water is higher at greater depths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 621, 227]]<|/det|>
The weight of the submarine is greater at greater depths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 106, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 656, 272]]<|/det|>
Which block exerts the greatest pressure on the surface below it?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 282, 230, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 905, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 521, 106, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 539, 540]]<|/det|>
A closed flask of gas is placed in a cold-water bath.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 549, 688, 747]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 586, 776]]<|/det|>
As the flask cools, the temperature of the gas decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 788, 477, 806]]<|/det|>
What happens to the molecules of the gas?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 816, 134, 834]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 816, 272, 833]]<|/det|>
They contract.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 843, 133, 861]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 843, 267, 860]]<|/det|>
They expand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 870, 131, 887]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 870, 361, 887]]<|/det|>
They move more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 896, 133, 914]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 896, 356, 913]]<|/det|>
They move more slowly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 816, 107]]<|/det|> A block of ice cream is prevented from melting by wrapping it in newspaper soaked water evaporates from the newspaper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 870, 152]]<|/det|> Which molecules escape from the water and what happens to the average speed of the molecules that remain in the newspaper? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 163, 668, 308]]<|/det|>

The graph shows how the temperature of each liquid changes with time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 375, 792, 570]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 581, 497, 602]]<|/det|> What does the graph tell us about the liquids? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 611, 136, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 611, 547, 630]]<|/det|> Liquid 1 has a higher melting point than liquid 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 637, 134, 655]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 637, 542, 655]]<|/det|> Liquid 1 has a higher boiling point than liquid 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 664, 134, 682]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 664, 500, 682]]<|/det|> Liquid 1 starts to melt sooner than liquid 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 134, 708]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 691, 497, 708]]<|/det|> Liquid 1 starts to boil sooner than liquid 2.

The air next to the metal becomes hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 526, 441]]<|/det|> The density of the air changes and the air moves. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 451, 683, 545]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 558, 845, 577]]<|/det|> Which row shows the density change of the air and the direction in which the air moves? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 482, 715]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 488, 107, 505]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|> Water waves may be used to demonstrate refraction by making them pass into water of a different depth. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 528, 747, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 679, 771, 698]]<|/det|> Why does the water wave change direction as it passes into the shallow water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 707, 134, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 470, 726]]<|/det|> The frequency of the wave decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 734, 134, 753]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 734, 465, 753]]<|/det|> The frequency of the wave increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 134, 780]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 761, 440, 780]]<|/det|> The speed of the wave decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 134, 806]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 787, 432, 804]]<|/det|> The speed of the wave increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 816, 92]]<|/det|>
Infra-red waves, microwaves, radio waves and sound waves are all used for commu

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 101, 594, 121]]<|/det|>
Which waves travel at the same high speed in a vacuum?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 129, 134, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 532, 149]]<|/det|>
infra-red waves, microwaves and radio waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 156, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 155, 542, 175]]<|/det|>
infra-red waves, microwaves and sound waves
